dt: {bc}to keep in one's pay or service

pt: {sc}keep{/sc} {sc}retain{/sc} {sc}detain{/sc} {sc}withhold{/sc} {sc}reserve{/sc} mean to hold in one's possession or under one's control. {sc}keep{/sc} may suggest a holding securely in one's possession, custody, or control.
{sc}retain{/sc} implies continued keeping, especially against threatened seizure or forced loss.

pt.t: managed to {it}retain{/it} their dignity even in poverty

pt: {sc}detain{/sc} suggests a delay in letting go.
{sc}withhold{/sc} implies restraint in letting go or a refusal to let go.
{sc}reserve{/sc} suggests a keeping in store for future use.

pt.t: {it}reserve{/it} some of your energy for the last mile

et: Middle English {it}reteinen, retainen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}retenir, reteigner{/it}, from Latin {it}retinēre{/it} to hold back, restrain, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}tenēre{/it} to hold {ma}{mat|thin|}{/ma}
shortdef: to keep in possession or use
to keep in one's pay or service; specifically : to employ by paying a retainer
to keep in mind or memory : remember

dt: {bc}a wall that is built to keep the land behind it from sliding

shortdef: a wall that is built to keep the land behind it from sliding
